PROJECT AT A GLANCE 

  

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Water Sector 
Investment Program. 
 
2. 
The investment program will help water supply companies in Viet Nam to improve their 
performance.  It  will  support  capital investment  in  water  companies  and  cofinance  the  National 
Nonrevenue  Water  (NRW)  Program.  The  program  will  utilize  an  MFF  to  provide  longer-term 
support for institutional reform in the Viet Nam water sector until 2020. The MFF will be used as 
seed  money  to  leverage  parallel  cofinancing  and,  importantly,  gain  access  to  commercial 
finance and increased private sector participation. Four pilot cities—Da Nang, Haiphong, Ho Chi 
Minh City (HCMC), and Hue—were identified for project preparation in 2008.1 The first periodic 
financing request (PFR) will cover HCMC. Subsequent tranches will finance part of the National 
NRW  Program  and  investment  subprograms  consisting  of  water  supply  infrastructure  for 
provincial  water  companies,  duplicating  the  model  established  with  HCMC  in  PFR1.    Several 
cities  have  initiated  discussions  with  the  government  to  finance  future  tranches  totaling  over 
$300 million for water production plants, transmission and distribution networks. 
 

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Sector  performance. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) water and sanitation sector 
assessment  strategy  and  road  map 2  shows  that  Viet  Nam’s  water  sector  has  significantly 
improved coverage since 1995. However, significant gaps remain in the quality and reliability of 
service.  Areas  requiring  water  companies’  attention  are  (i)  financial  sustainability,  (ii)  the 
efficiency  and  accountability  of  decentralized  sector  institutions,  and  (iii)  data  on  utility  assets 
and performance. The proposed program will address those three areas. Further, NRW in Viet 
Nam cities is still unacceptably high, averaging 30% and reaching 40%.3 To meet government 
targets and improve the financial viability of water companies, considerable effort is required to 
identify losses and mount a program of massive pipe replacement. ADB will support operational 
work on distribution networks necessary to identify causes of NRW and finance pipe repair and 
replacement.  ADB’s  proposed  methodology  promotes  water  company  ownership  of  the  NRW 
reduction program by including NRW as a core target of operation and maintenance.  
 
Policy  framework. The policy and legal basis for the sector is relatively strong, as the 
4. 
government  issued  two  key  decisions  detailing  a  clear  vision  and  setting  targets  and 
implementation  measures.  The  water  supply  decree 4  transforms  water  from  a  social  to  a 
commercial  commodity  and  requires  water  supply  tariffs  to  be  set  for  full  cost  recovery,

the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Preparing Hue Water Supply Project. Manila (TA 7089-VIE). 

2  The document was completed in June 2010 by the ADB Viet Nam water team.  
3  NRW is the portion of water produced but not sold because of physical losses from old pipes and poor installation, 
commercial  losses  from  stolen  water,  defective  meters,  and  non-commercial  uses  such  as  cleaning  and  
firefighting. NRW below 20% indicates a very good operation of the distribution network. 

4   Decree 117/2007/ND-CP on Clean Water Production, Supply and Consumption 

 addressing  the  main  recommendation5 from  ADB’s  Independent  Evaluation  Department.  The 
orientation plan for urban water supply6 and the Decision on NRW7 set ambitious targets for the 
water sector, in particular for reducing NRW to 25% by 2015 and 18% by 2020. The objectives 
of the government’s current socioeconomic development plan, 2006–2010 for the water sector 
include  providing  essential  water  supply  and  sanitation  infrastructure  to  poor  households  in 
cities and towns across the country and enhancing cost recovery for infrastructure investments 
by  setting  and  collecting  appropriate  tariffs  and  fees.  ADB’s  sector  program  in  its  country 
strategy  and  program,  2007–2010  is  consistent  with  these  policies  and  was  confirmed  by  the 
country  operations  business  plan,  2009–2011  and  the  midterm  review  of  the  country  strategy 
and  program  in  2009. 8 The  strategy  explicitly  aims  to  give  substance  to  the  government’s 
initiatives  to  decentralize  planning,  financing,  and  decision  making  and  to  support  the  current 
legal  framework  in  the  water  sector.  The  investment  program  will  contribute  to  the  water 
operational framework,9 which emphasizes water availability and water security. The investment 
program  improves  efficiency  in  the  water  sector  and  addresses  the  supply–demand  gap, 
resource protection, storage improvement, the impact of technology (especially for NRW), and 
health through the implementation of water safety plans10 to provide drinking water.  
 
5. 
Multitranche  financing  facility.  Ongoing  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  for 
water  supply  projects  in  Viet  Nam  highlights  the  need  to  provide  flexible  financing  to  support 
longer-term,  phased  investment  and  implementation  of  institutional  reform.  As  several  cities 
have requested ADB financing, a series of stand-alone investment loans would be inadequate. 
A  program  or  sector  loan  would  not  provide  the  necessary  supervision  during  project 
implementation to address shortcomings in the new legislative framework for the sector. It is too 
early  to  implement  credit  lines  to  financial  institutions  pending  the  new  legislation  on  public–
private partnerships and the water law.  
 
6. 
Project  1. HCMC is Viet Nam’s largest city and an important commercial and industrial 
center.  Its  population  of  7.1  million  is  growing  by  3.5%  per  annum  and  likely  to  surpass  10 
million  by  2020.  While  Viet  Nam’s  gross  domestic  product  is  growing  by  more  than  8%  per 
annum,  HCMC’s  gross  domestic  product  is  growing  substantially  faster,  by  11%.  This  growth 
rate is seriously straining the city’s infrastructure, including the water supply system. In addition, 
HCMC  is  one  of  the  10  cities  in  the  world  likely  to  experience  the  early  impacts  of  climate 
change, in particular a projected sea level rise of 33 centimeters by 2050. 
 
7. 
Saigon  Water  Corporation  (SAWACO),  set  up  in  1874,  is  Viet  Nam’s  oldest  water 
company  and  responsible  for  water  supply  in  HCMC.  It  has  operated  since  2004  as  a  state-
owned  one-member  company  limited  under  the  Commercial  Law,  2005.  Six  distribution 
companies, incorporated as joint stock companies and 51% owned by SAWACO, and two other 
companies under SAWACO are in  charge of distribution in HCMC. SAWACO has  proposed a

and private sector participation in the water sector. SAWACO has asked ADB to help formulate 
a  private  sector  development  framework  during  program  implementation.  The  framework  will 
define  which  investments  in  the  $2.8  billion  investment  plan  of  SAWACO  (until  2025)  can  be 
financed  by  the  private  sector  as  well  as  improve  the  enabling  environment  to  attract  such 
financing. A similar framework will be developed for the other cities to optimize ADB lending.  
 
8. 
For Project 1 in HCMC, the water supply system has five major production plants with a 
total  capacity  of  1.34  million  cubic  meters  per  day  (m3/day)  and  3,800  kilometers  (km)  of 
distribution  network  with  734,000  connections,  divided  into  six  zones.  The  fundamental 
constraint on the water supply system is a shortfall in transmission capacity. Actual coverage is 
estimated at 82%, but large areas of HCMC, especially in the south, still suffer intermittent water 
supply  because  of  low  service  pressure.  The  proposed  investment  program  is  in  line  with 
HCMC’s  draft  master  plan  to  be  approved  in  2011,  whose  objectives  are  to  achieve  universal 
coverage, continuous water supply, and drinking water quality in HCMC by 2025. 
 
HCMC’s  NRW  is  estimated  at  40%.  The  World  Bank  supports  a  number  of  initiatives 
9. 
under  way  to  reduce  NRW  in  the  city  center  zones  1  and  2,  and  the  Government  of  the 
Netherlands supports an ongoing Utility Support Program. ADB’s assistance is sought for NRW 
in  the  two  southern  zones  5  and  6.  Private  sector  participation  is  being  explored  for  capital 
investment in NRW and the operation and maintenance of the network in the northern zones 3 
and 4. Two water production plants are operated by the private sector: Binh An, under a build–
operate–transfer contract and Thu Duc 2, under a build–own–operate contract. 
 
The investment program will mitigate poverty by improving coverage and the provision of 
10. 
basic services in HCMC. Addressing the most urgent constraints on SAWACO, it will increase 
distribution  capacity  to  benefit  475,000  households  in  zones  1  and  3  with  improved  pressure 
and  coverage  by  installing  a  transmission  pipe  with  a  diameter  of  2,400  millimeters  (mm)  for 
treated water; improve pressure and coverage for 33,872 households in zones 3, 4, 5, and 6 by 
rehabilitating and replacing distribution pipes; provide 13,273 poor households with water supply 
for the first time and 6,500 poor households that previously shared connections with their own 
connection  for  first  time;  strengthen  operational  management  through  a  comprehensive 
information  and  communication  technology  program;  and  (iii)  support  the  development  of  a 
climate change action plan and strengthen safeguards for SAWACO.

14. 
Technical  assistance  under  project  1  will  implement  institutional  reforms  mostly  under 
the information and communication technology component. The geographic information system 
will  allow  asset  inventory  and  management,  and  the  management  and  financial  information 
systems will allow the monitoring of benchmarking and the continuous improvement process.  
 
D. 
 
15. 
The government intends to invest $2.78 billion in the Viet Nam water sector by 2020. It 
has  requested  an  MFF  of  up  to  $1.00  billion  from  ADB's  ordinary  capital  resources  to  help 
finance  the  investment.  The  MFF  will  have  several  tranches,  subject  to  the  government's 
submission  of  PFRs;  execution  of  loan  and  project  agreements;  and  fulfillment  of  terms, 
conditions,  and  undertakings  set  forth  in  the  framework  financing  agreement.  The  indicative 
investment plan for the MFF is in Table 1.

 III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
22. 
In parallel with the MFF, the project team is processing a series of technical assistance 
and  associated  projects.  A  $1.5  million  capacity  development  technical  assistance  grant  in 
2011–2012  will  help  water  companies  participating  in  future  tranches  of  the  MFF  and  water 
companies  in  the  Third  Provincial  Towns  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  Project16 improve  their 
efficiency by supporting their preparation of operational business plans and action plans to meet 
agreed  performance  indicators.  The  technical  assistance  will  also  outline  the  National  NRW 
Program and build capacity in the MPI to coordinate and report on the MFF in 2011 and 2012. 
Two grants of $2 million each from the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility will finance 
investment  to  improve  energy  efficiency  in  2011  and  2012.  Two  grants  of  $3  million  each  will 
address  water  supply  to  remote  and  rural  locations  in  the  provinces  of  Hue  in  2011  and  Da 
Nang in 2012. 
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

 
Project  preparation  for  HCMC  was  completed  in  March  2010,  and  due  diligence  has 
23. 
been  carried  out  for  project  1.  The  ADB  project  team  set  a  tariff  increase  as  a  condition  for 
appraisal. After 6 years without any tariff review, HCMC pushed through a long overdue water 
tariff increase of 48% that became effective in March 2010, with further annual increases of 10% 
until  2013.  The  road  map  for  water  tariffs  in  HCMC  will  be  revised  at  the  midterm  review  in 
2013.  
 
24. 
As  the  investment  program  will  be  financed  through  loans from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources  for  the  first  time  in  the  water  sector  in  Viet  Nam,  participating  water  companies  will 
need to demonstrate a strong commitment to institutional reform. The primary selection criterion 
for projects to be financed in subsequent tranches is a demonstrated commitment to operating 
at  full  cost  recovery  through  water  tariff  reform  (including  an  increased  water  tariff,  an 
agreement  on  a  water  tariff  road  map,  and  the  phasing  out  of  subsidies  and  direct  charges) 
linked  to  hard  targets  for  selected  performance  indicators.  Other  selection  criteria  are  a 
commitment to national water policies such as (i) agreement on a service contract and business 
plan; (ii) NRW reduction by 10% over 10 years, or to 18% by 2020; (iii) over 90% coverage in 
urban areas and 70% in rural areas by 2020; and (iv) implementation of water safefy plans from 
World Health Organization, in order to provide access to safe water. 
 
A. 
 
25. 
SAWACO  is  completing  detailed  design  of  the  $57.5  million  10  km,  2,400  mm 
transmission  pipe,  with  construction  to  start  as  soon  as  the  loan  is  declared  effective  or  to  be 
financed  retroactively  if  loan  effectiveness  is  delayed.  The  framework  financing  agreement 
provides  selection  criteria  for  projects’  eligibility  for  financing  under  the  MFF,  which  include 
feasibility study reports being vetted and approved by the government and ADB. 
 
B. 
 
26. 
Financial and economic analyses have been done for project 1 in HCMC. The financial 
internal  rate  of  return  is  8.7%,  above  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  of  2.44%.  The 
economic internal rate of return for the first tranche is 24.5%, well above the social opportunity

C. 
 
27. 
SAWACO’s  financial  management  and  procurement  capacity  have  been  assessed.  A 
project administration manual has been completed for project 1, as has a facility administration 
manual for the MFF. PMU staff for projects 1 and 2 have started training on ADB systems and 
procedures for procurement and disbursement, which will continue in 2011.  
 
28. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to the MPI and 
SAWACO.  Specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are  described  in  the 
facility  administration  manual  for  the  MFF  and  the  project  administration  manual  for  project  1 
(footnote 15). 
 
D. 
 
29. 
HCMC’s overall poverty rate of 12% disguises poverty rates of more than 50% in some 
wards  and  districts.  The  urban  poor  are  both  long-term  residents  and  migrant  households. 
Surveys  show  a  low  incidence  of  waterborne  disease.  Satisfaction  with  SAWACO’s  service  is 
good  overall,  despite  some  dissatisfaction  because  of  poor  water  quality.  Among  households 
connected to piped water, 84% have individual connections, 12% shared connections with their 
own meter, and 4% shared connections with a shared meter. Many households buy water from 
tankers  and  pay  almost  twice  the  official  water  tariff  of  D4,000–D10,000  per  cubic  meter. 
Although  policy  dictates  free  connections,  the  tertiary  distribution  network  is  obviously  lacking 
and will be extended under the program by the component that rehabilitates and replaces pipes. 
 
The  social  assessment  concluded  that  information  dissemination,  education,  and 
30. 
communication are required at the ward level. The social development services subcomponent 
under project 1 aims to increase community participation in water supply services. The focus will 
be on strengthening the role of the ward-level community supervision boards in project areas by 
improving  members’  knowledge  of  the  water  supply  system  and  proposed  works,  including 
resettlement,  improving  capacity  in  community  participation  and  monitoring,  and  improving 
coordination among members.  
 
Project 1 is categorized as effective in gender mainstreaming. A gender assessment in 
31. 
HCMC during preparation for project 1 found that women play a key role in ensuring that water 
is  available  in  the  home,  collecting  and  paying  for  water,  and  teaching  children  about  water 
conservation.  The  Women’s  Union  is  neither  formally  included  in  any  water  decision-making 
body  nor  consulted  by  SAWACO.  Key  gender  issues  to  be  addressed  by  the  project  include 
(i) the  gender  and  poverty  implications  of  water  access  and  usage;  (ii)  women’s  increased 
involvement  in  water  utility  agencies,  community  supervision  boards,  and  operation  and 
maintenance; and (iii) sex-disaggregated data on poverty and water supply access. 
 
Project 1 includes a gender action plan17 that ensures (i) the development of a road map 
32. 
for  water  tariff  increases  that  considers  gender  and  affordability  issues;  (ii)  network  extension 
covers 100% of households headed by women in project areas; (iii) the implementation of the 
water  supply  decree  (footnote  5)  to  ensure  lifeline  tariff  and  free  connections  are  provided  to

employment in operation and maintenance at the commune or ward level; (v) the participation of 
women  and  the  Women’s  Union  in  ward  committees;  (vi)  gender-sensitive  information 
dissemination,  education,  and  communication  using  community  women  as  facilitators  for

companies,  the  PMU,  and  consultants  and  the  inclusion  in  the  project  monitoring  system  of  a 
sex-disaggregated database. 
 
E. 
 
The project is classified category B as resettlement is largely limited to where the 2,400 
33. 
mm  treated  water  pipeline  will  be  constructed,  together  with  road  widening.  Pipe  replacement 
and  extension  will  use  existing  rights  of  way,  where  possible.  Conventional  civil  works  will  be 
employed to lay the 2,400 mm pipeline in three sections of the selected corridor. A resettlement 
framework was prepared, instead of a resettlement plan, because the alignment and routing of 
the  pipelines  will  be  finalized  only  during  detailed  design.  The  resettlement  framework  and 
resettlement  plan  for  one  subcomponent  was  prepared  according  to  government  regulations 
and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and in consultation with local communities and 
authorities.  The  cost  estimates  include  the  provision  of  $0.6  million  for  resettlement  cost  and 
$250,000 for monitoring and evaluating resettlement. 
 
34. 
The project is classified category B for environmental impacts. An initial environmental 
examination was undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement to assess 
potential  environmental  impacts  and  propose  mitigation  and  institutional  arrangements.  It 
indicates  that  adverse  environmental  impacts  will  be  insignificant.  The  PMU  will  prepare  an 
annual  monitoring  report  for  submission  to  the  Department  of  Natural  Resources  and 
Environment for endorsement before submission to ADB. 
 
35. 
Ethnic  minority  households  are  well  integrated  into  mainstream  urban  society  in  all 
aspects  of  life,  including  language,  clothing,  housing,  and  economic  activities.  The  project  is 
categorized C, since it will have positive impacts on ethnic minorities, as it improves access to 
water. 
 
36. 
Preparation  of  future  tranches  preparation  will  be  guided  by  the  safeguard  framework 
documents18 and  loan  fact-finding  missions  will  secure  the  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy Statement for each tranche.  
 
F. 
 
37. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

The major risks are as follows:  
(i) 

The  central  and  local  governments  may  delay  processing  because  of  the 
structuring of this first sectoral MFF in Viet Nam and the new decision (footnote 
14)  defining  a  new  format  for  feasibility  studies  for  projects  financed  by  official 
development assistance (ODA), which was not well received by local government 
agencies or ministries. The project team asked the MPI to help build awareness 
in local governments of the new requirement for feasibility study reports.

Local governments may fail to enforce water tariff increases for full cost recovery, 
threatening  the  financial  sustainability  of  the  investment  program.  Substantial 
tariff increases, a road map to full cost recovery, and the phasing out of subsidies 
to comply with Viet Nam legislation are conditions for subprojects’ qualifying for 
financing under the MFF.  
The equitization of water companies without adequate oversight will not improve 
service delivery. Without a service contract or a business plan, water companies 
are  accountable  only  to  make  a  best  effort.  Another  regulatory  issue  is  water 
companies venturing outside their core business into high-risk investments such 
as real estate. Under the MFF, water companies will ring-fence the accounts for 
water  operation  and  report  in  a  transparent  manner  performance  data,  as  a 
precondition to attract investment capital from ODA or the private sector. 
Political  interference  can  undermine  successful  implementation  and  financial 
sustainability. The project will strengthen awareness through high-level advocacy 
of  the  benefits  of  reliable  water  supply  and  financially  strong  and  accountable 
water companies in Viet Nam and the region. 
Decentralization  and  granting  greater  autonomy  to  local  government  agencies 
and utilities are not matched with improved accountability to consumers or higher 
levels  of  government.  The  project  performance  management  system  introduces 
new  meaningful  indicators  on  financial  sustainability.  The  government  is 
implementing  benchmarking  through  the  Ministry  of  Construction  and  the  Viet 
Nam Water Supply and Sewerage Association. 

V. 

ASSURANCES 

 
38. 
The government, the MPI, and SAWACO have assured ADB that implementation of the 
investment  program  and  project  1 shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those 
concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and 
disbursement as described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
39. 
The government and the MPI have given ADB certain undertakings for the MFF, as set 
forth in the framework financing agreement. Specific covenants agreed by the government, the 
MPI, and water companies with respect to individual tranches under the MFF will be set forth in 
the loan agreement and project agreement for each tranche.  
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
40. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  multitranche  financing  facility  would  comply  with  the 
Articles  of  Agreement  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board 
approve the provision of loans under the multitranche financing facility in an aggregate principal 
amount  not  exceeding  $1,000,000,000  to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Water 
Sector  Investment  Program  from  ADB's  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be 
determined in accordance with ADB's LIBOR-based lending facility, and such other terms and 
conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  framework  financing 
agreement presented to the Board.
